column12: How many ways can you get a 1 pair?
column26: For a 1 pair, we want 2 cards of the same face and any suit. From the 13 faces,  choose 1 for the pair: \(\binom{13}{1}\). From the 4 suits,  choose any 2 suits for the pair: \(\binom{4}{2}\). The remaining 3 cards can be any face, except for the face appearing in the pair. From the 12 remaining faces,  choose 3: \(\binom{12}{3}\). The remaining 3 cards can be any suit, regardless of whether it was used in the pair: \(\binom{4}{1}^3\).

column12: How many ways can you get a 2 pair?
column26: For a 2 pair, we want 2 cards of the same face, any suit and another 2 cards of their own same face, any suit. From the 13 faces,  choose 2 for the pairs: \(\binom{13}{2}\). From the 4 suits, choose 2 for each pair: \(\binom{4}{2}^2\). The remaining card can be any face, except for the 2 faces appearing in the 2 pairs: \(\binom{11}{1}\). The remaining card can be any suit, regardless of whether it was used in either of the 2 paris: (\binom{4}{1}\).

column12: How many ways can you get a 3 of a kind?
column26: For a 3 of a kind, we want 3 cards of the same face and any suit. From the 13 faces, choose 1 for the 3 of a kind: \(\binom{13}{1}\). From the 4 faces, choose any 3 for the 3 of a kind: \(\binom{4}{3}\). The remaining 2 cards can be any face, except for the face appearing in the 3 of a kind: \(binom{12}{2}\). The remaining cards can be any suit, regardless of whether it was used in the 3 of a kind: \(\binom{4}{1}^2\).

column12: How many ways can you get a straight?
column26: For a straight, we want all 5 cards to be of sequential faces and any suit. However, king, queen, and jack are not included in a straight as they are in their own special type of hand called a royal flush. Additionally, aces are included only as a low ace. From the 10 faces, choose 1: \(\binom{10}{1}\). From the 4 suits, choose 1 for each card: \(\binom{4}{1}^5\). Finally, subtract out the number of ways you could be dealt a straight flush: \(\binom{10}{1}\binom{4}{1}\).

column12: How many ways can you get a flush?
column26: For a flush, we want all 5 cards to be of the same suit and any face. Additionally, we cannot include the special type of flush called a straight flush. From the 13 faces, choose 5 for the flush: \(\binom{13}{5}\). From the 4 suits, choose only 1 for all 5 cards: \(\binom{4}{1}\). Finally, subtract out the number of ways you could be dealt a straight flush: \(\-binom{10}{1}\binom{4}{1}\).

column12: How many ways can you get a full house?
column26: For a full house, we want a 3 of a kind and 1 pair. For a 3 of a kind, we want 3 cards of the same face and any suit. From the 13 faces, choose 1 for the 3 of a kind: \(\binom{13}{1}\). From the 4 faces, choose any 3 for the 3 of a kind: \(\binom{4}{3}\). The remaining 2 cards must be a pair. For the 1 pair, we want 2 cards of any suit and any face, except for the face appearing in the 3 of a kind. From the 12 faces,  choose 1 for the pair: \(\binom{12}{1}\). From the 4 suits, choose any 2 suits for the pair: \(\binom{4}{2}\).

column26: For a 4 of a kind, we want 4 cards to be of the same face and any suit. From the 13 faces, choose 1 for the 4 cards: \(\binom{13}{1}\). From the 4 suits, choose any 4 for all 4 cards: \(\binom{4}{4}\). The remaining card can be any suit and any face, exceot for the face appearing in the 4 of a kind. column12: How many ways can you get a straight flush?
column26: For a straight flush, we want all 5 cards to be of sequential faces and the same suit. Like the straight, king, queen, and jack are not included in a straight flush and are only included in a special type of straight flush called a royal flush. Additionally, aces are included only as a low ace. From the 10 faces, choose 1: \(\binom{10}{1}\). From the 4 suits, choose only 1 for all 5 cards: \(\binom{4}{1}\). Finally, subtract out the number of ways you could be dealt a royal flush: \(\binom{4}{1}\).

column12: How many ways can you get a royal flush?
column26: For a royal flush, we want a straight flush with an ace as the high card. Within a single suit, there is only 1 possible way to be dealt these 5 faces. Since there are 4 suits, multiply this 1 possible way times 4. In other words, choose 1 card from a pool of 1 option for each of the 5 cards: \(\binom{1}{1}^5\). From the 4 suits, choose 1 suit for all 5 cards: \(\binom{4}{1}\).
